titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nina Berberova Collection
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:12

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Nina Berberova Collection contains correspondence, writings, printed material, photographs, audiovisual recordings and electronic files by and relating to Nina Berberova, especially the latter decades of her life. The material was collected and donated by Murl Barker and John Malmstad.

langmaterial.language: The collection is in Russian and English and includes translations of some letters from Russian to English.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Berberova, N. (Nina.) ( Bii︠a︡nkurskie prazdniki i drugie rasskazy)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of John Malmstad, 2004 and Murl Barker, 2005.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Box 18: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies are available for electronic documents. Consult Access Services for further information. For other materials, reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Box 19 (audio cassettes): Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Nina Berberova Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nina Berberova Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Audiocassettes have been reformatted as digital files.

bioghist.head: Nina Nikolaevna Berberova (1901-1993)
bioghist.p: Nina Nikolaevna Berberova was born on August 8, 1901 (July 26, 1901, old style) in St. Petersburg, Russia. Her autobiography, Kursiv moi (first published in English as The Italics are Mine ), details her life as an emigre and writer up to approximately 1957.

After living in Paris for twenty five years, Berberova emigrated to the United States in 1950. She began her academic career in 1958 at Yale University. She continued to write while she was teaching, publishing several povesti, critical articles and some poetry. She left Yale in 1963 for Princeton University, where she taught until her retirement in 1971. For Berberova "retirement" meant visiting as a lecturer at Cornell, Columbia, Bryn Mawr and the University of Pennsylvania, teaching during the summer in the Russian School at Middlebury College, and writing. During these years she was awarded honorary degrees from Glasboro State College (1980), Middlebury College (1983), and Yale University (1992).
In 1991 Berberova moved from Princeton, New Jersey to Philadelphia. She lived there until she died September 27, 1993 from complications from a fall.
Readers may consult Nina Berberova Papers, GEN MSS 182for further description of Nina Berberova's life and work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nina Berberova Collection contains correspondence, writings, printed material, photographs, audiovisual recordings and electronic files by and relating to Nina Berberova. The material was collected and donated by Murl Barker and John Malmstad and mostly relates to the later decades of Berberova's life.

Series I was collected and donated by Berberova's former student Murl Barker, whom she met in the early 1960s at Yale University. They continued a close friendship until Berberova's death in 1993. Barker's collection includes correspondence, writings, printed material, photographs, audiovisual recordings and electronic files documenting Berberova's career, especially after her emigration to the United States in 1950.
Series II, donated by John Malmstad, consists chiefly of letters from Berberova to Malmstad.

Many of the relationships, writings and events documented in this collection are also documented in the Nina Berberova Papers, GEN MSS 182. Barker's letters to Berberova are in her papers, while Berberova's letters to Barker are in this collection. Berberova's papers contain material related to many of her publications; additional typescripts and holograph notes are in this collection. This collection contains two holograph journals and one photocopy of a journal that are not in Berberova's papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Nina Berberova Collection is organized into two series: Murl Barker Collection of Nina Berberova and John Malmstad Collection of Nina Berberova.

did.unittitle: Murl Barker Collection of Nina Berberova

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into five subseries: Correspondence, Writings, Personal Papers and Effects, Photographs and Artwork and Audiovisual Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains papers collected by Berberova's student Murl Barker. These include correspondence, typescripts and drafts of Berberova's writings and Barker's writings on Berberova, photographic snapshots and portraits and audiovisual recordings of Berberova's interviews and readings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Correspondence is organized under two headings. Berberova's correspondence is filed first. Barker's correspondence related to Berberova follows.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the correspondence in this subseries consists of letters from Berberova to Murl Barker. The letters are largely personal, documenting Berberova's travels, relationships, navigation through American life and the growth of her literary recognition. Later letters address legal and administrative topics regarding Berberova's estate and papers.

did.unittitle: Ingram Merrill Foundation, incoming and outgoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sent via Vitalii Vul'f; accompanied by a copy of a 1973 letter from Berberova to Lili IUr'evna [Brik]

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Writings are organized under six headings: Books, Stories, Poetry, Plays, Subject Files and Murl Barker Writings on Berberova. Under each heading, works are arranged alphabetically. Two groups of documents labeled "Unpublished by Nyssen" and "Stories discarded" are filed at the end of Stories.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The writings in this series are mostly drafts and copies of Berberova's stories that reflect the editorial process of producing collected volumes. Several folders contain the stories published in Biiankurskie Prazdniki . Some early stories from Russian emigre newspaper publications in Paris are labeled "discarded." Berberova very lightly corrected or annotated some of these. In addition to stories, writings by Berberova include one play, one folder of poems in English, the introduction to a 1997 edition of her biography of Chaikovskii and two subject files.
The subseries also contains collected writings by Murl Barker about Berberova, including several short papers and biographical entries. These papers include one computer disk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All are copies of printed versions unless otherwise noted

did.unittitle: Biiankurskie Prazkniki i Drugie Rasskazy , copy of typescript and manuscript draft

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by a note by Murl Barker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Accompanied by notes by Murl Barker

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This group of stories is arranged in the order in which it was received.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unless otherwise noted, the short stories filed together under the label of "Stories discarded" are printed versions (some accompanied by photocopies). Although no positive identification is evident, the printed versions dating from the 1930s are likely clippings from Poslednie Novosti [ The Latest News ], a Russian emigre journal published in Paris. Some copies were made from the B.I. Nicolaevsky Collection at the Hoover Institution, Stanford University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Personal papers are arranged roughly chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains journals, personal papers, ephemera and personal effects. The personal papers include legal, financial and medical papers.
Many of Berberova's journals are located in the Nina Berberova Papers (GEN MSS 182), a separately cataloged collection. The additional journals and diaries in this series complement that collection.

did.unittitle: Ephemera and correspondence related to honorary degree from Yale
Marriage certificate of George Kochevitskii and Nina Berberova
"Zapiski iz publiki" [Notes from the public], manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These slips of paper contain questions posed by members of the audience during Berberova's public appearance(s) in Moscow in 1989

did.physloc: Also stored in: Oversize, Box 15 folders 143-144.

did.unittitle: Printed material and ephemera from the Colloque international Nina Berberova, Arles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box of personal effects contains a medal from Berberova's designation as Chevalier of the Order of Arts and Letters (France, 1989), three watches, one ring, one chain and a small purse

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Dated photographs are arranged chronologically followed by one folder of undated photographs. One oil painting is filed at the end of the subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Almost all photographs are of Berberova and most are snapshots, although a few are professional portraits. Most of the photographs have been identified by Murl Barker and the folder descriptions reflect his notes. Besides Berberova, identified subjects include Murl and Jackie Barker, George Kochevitskii, Marcello Mastroianni and Hubert and Christine Nyssen.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Audiocassettes have been reformatted as digital files. The original cassettes are filed in Restricted Fragile and may be accessed only with the permission of the curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Audiovisual Material is organized under two headings: Audiocassettes and Videocassettes. Under each heading material is arranged roughly chronologically. Undated material is filed at the end of each heading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audiovisual material contains recordings of Berberova reading poetry, interviews with Berberova and unidentified material. Folder titles are based on notes and labels accompanying the cassettes.

John Malmstad Collection of Nina Berberova

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers donated by John Malmstad chiefly consist of letters written to him by Berberova. The letters are largely personal but they also document Berberova's progress in publishing her work and her interest in the literary legacy of Vladislav Khodasevich. In addition to correspondence, the series contains one folder of other papers and one photograph portrait.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, Nina Berberova to John Malmstad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes: course syllabus, lecture notes, copy of newspaper clipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Boxes 18-19 contain fragile originals. The material is arranged in folder order and may be accessed only with the permission of the appropriate curator. Access to electronic files is available through public services. Reference copies of audio recordings have been substituted in the main files for reference use.
